task.title: Create a security group using the User Console

taskbody.context: In this section of the lab exercise you will create a security group using the Eucaluptus User Console.Â Then you will add a firewall rule to your security group.

step.cmd: In the User Console, click the Network & Security icon and then select Security Groups.

info.p: The Manage security groups window opens.

step.cmd: Click the Create new security group button.

info.p: The Create new security group window opens.

step.cmd: Fill out the Create new security group form. Name the security group mygroup and provide the description of another security group. Select SSH (TCP port 22, for terminal access) for the Protocol. Allow access from the network 0.0.0.0/0. Click Create.

info.p: The new security group is listed in the Manage security groups window.

step.cmd: Click the Images icon to navigate to the Manage images window.
Click the Launch instances button next to your EMI image that is in the kvm-centos bucket.
Accept the default vmtype, number of instances, and availability zone and click the Next: Select security button.
Accept the default key pair and select your mygroup security group from the drop-down menu. Then click the Launch instance(s) to launch the instance. Allow the instance to reach a running status.
Remain logged in to the User Console.
Open an xterm window on the Debian desktop and then use SSH to log in to your running instance.

info.p: Did it work? You might have received a security warning message from the ssh command. If you did, the problem is that the instance's IP address was formerly used by a previous instance and its security key information is cached in the /root/.ssh/known_hosts file. You will need to edit this file and remove the entry associated with your current instance's IP address. You will have to do this each time the IP address is reused by a new instance. While it is less secure, you could also create an shell alias for the ssh command in the shell startup file, for example the .bashrc file. The alias would have the syntax alias ssh='ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no'.

step.cmd: Exit from the instance and close the xterm window.
